items.title: Dynamic Cooperative Strategies in Search Engine Advertising Market: With and Without Retail Competition
items.authors: Huiran Li, Qiucheng Li, Baozhu Feng
items.institution: Shanghai Customs College, Anhui University of Finance and Economics
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a novel dynamic cooperative advertising optimization model for the SEA market that incorporates direct manufacturer advertising and retailer subsidies. 2. Analyzes two distinct scenarios (with and without retail competition) and provides feasible equilibrium solutions for optimal policies. 3. Investigates the impact of key factors like dynamic quality scores, gross margin, and competitor market share through numerical experiments and sensitivity analysis.
items.summary: This paper models cooperative advertising strategies in the search engine advertising (SEA) market using a differential game framework over a finite time horizon. It proposes an optimization model where a manufacturer can advertise directly and subsidize a retailer, analyzing scenarios with and without a competing independent retailer. The study provides equilibrium solutions and numerical insights, concluding that retail competition significantly impacts the optimal cooperative strategy and overall channel performance.

items.title: EFX Allocations Exist on Triangle-Free Multi-Graphs
items.authors: Mahyar Afshinmehr, Arash Ashuri, Pouria Mahmoudkhan, Kurt Mehlhorn
items.institution: Sharif University of Technology, Max Planck Institute for Informatics
items.contributions: 1. Proved the existence of EFX allocations for multi-graph valuations on triangle-free graphs, strengthening previous results. 2. Provided a pseudo-polynomial time algorithm to compute such allocations under monotone valuations. 3. Showed the algorithm runs in polynomial time for the broader class of cancelable valuations.
items.summary: This paper studies the fair allocation of indivisible goods to ensure envy-freeness up to any good (EFX). It proves that EFX allocations always exist when goods are represented as edges on a triangle-free multi-graph, and provides a computational algorithm for finding them. This result significantly expands the known conditions under which EFX allocations are guaranteed to exist for any number of agents.

items.title: Near-Optimal Coalition Structures in Polynomial Time
items.authors: Angshul Majumdar
items.institution: Indraprastha Institute of Information Technology, Delhi
items.contributions: 1. Proves that under a "sparse synergy" model, sparse relaxation methods can find near-optimal coalition structures in polynomial time with high probability. 2. Demonstrates that broad classes of dynamic programming and MILP algorithms require exponential time to achieve comparable solution quality. 3. Establishes a rigorous probabilistic anytime performance separation favoring sparse relaxations over exact methods for the CSG problem.
items.summary: This paper studies the coalition structure generation (CSG) problem. It compares three algorithmic paradigms and proves that, under a random sparse synergy model, sparse relaxation methods can find near-optimal solutions in polynomial time, while exact methods like DP and MILP require exponential time to reach similar quality, establishing a clear anytime performance advantage for the sparse approach.

items.title: Multi-agent Adaptive Mechanism Design
items.authors: Qiushi Han, David Simchi-Levi, Renfei Tan, Zishuo Zhao
items.institution: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign
items.contributions: 1. Introduces DRAM, a novel framework combining mechanism design and online learning to handle unknown agent beliefs. 2. Provides theoretical guarantees of high-probability truthfulness and achieves optimal $\tilde\{O\}(\sqrt\{T\})$ cumulative regret with a matching lower bound. 3. Generalizes the framework (DRAM+) to support plug-in estimators, structured priors, and delayed feedback.
items.summary: This paper addresses the problem of designing a truthful mechanism when the principal has no prior knowledge of agents' beliefs. It proposes the Distributionally Robust Adaptive Mechanism (DRAM), which iteratively learns beliefs and updates a robust optimization problem to minimize cost while ensuring truthfulness. The mechanism is proven to achieve optimal regret, and the framework is the first to maintain truthfulness under these general learning conditions.

        A --> D[关键结果/Results: Guaranteed truthfulness & optimal $\tilde{O}(\sqrt{T})$ regret]

items.title: Determining Blockchain Transaction Timing and Fee with Observable Mempools
items.authors: Qianlan Bai, Yuedong Xu, Zhijian Zhou, Xin Wang
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a novel transaction policy for a strategic user that jointly optimizes transaction broadcasting time and fee, considering observable mempools. 2. Derives optimal strategies for two user scenarios: mempool-oblivious users (with arbitrary mining interval distributions) and semi-strategic users (with Poisson fee updates). 3. Formulates a continuous-time Markov chain to model mempool dynamics and derives the optimal fee adjustment frequency for the strategic user.
items.summary: This paper investigates how a strategic user can optimize transaction broadcasting time and fee in blockchain systems with observable mempools and fee bumping. It analyzes optimal strategies under different user behavior models and block generation distributions (exponential for PoW, fixed for PoS). The key finding is that the strategic user should immediately increase the fee when it falls below the inclusion threshold.

items.title: Deep Learning Based Auction Design for Selling Agricultural Produce through Farmer Collectives to Maximize Nash Social Welfare
items.authors: Mayank Ratan Bhardwaj, Vishisht Srihari Rao, Bazil Ahmed, Kartik Sagar, Y. Narahari
items.institution: Plaksha University, Indian Institute of Science
items.contributions: 1. Proposes VDA-SAP, a novel deep learning-based volume discount auction for selling agricultural produce through Farmer Collectives. 2. Aims to maximize Nash social welfare while satisfying incentive compatibility, individual rationality, and practical business constraints, despite theoretical impossibility. 3. Demonstrates superiority over classical VCG and other baseline mechanisms in a realistic perishable goods setting.
items.summary: This paper addresses the problem of designing a fair and efficient market for agricultural produce by proposing a deep learning-based volume discount auction (VDA-SAP) for Farmer Collectives. The mechanism aims to maximize Nash social welfare while approximately satisfying key economic properties. The results show it outperforms traditional mechanisms like VCG in this practical setting.

items.title: Sharing with Frictions: Limited Transfers and Costly Inspections
items.authors: Federico Bobbio, Randall A. Berry, Michael L. Honig, Thanh Nguyen, Vijay G. Subramanian, Rakesh V. Vohra
items.institution: Northwestern University, Purdue University, University of Michigan, University of Pennsylvania
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a novel mechanism design formulation for resource allocation with private information and without direct monetary transfers. 2. Characterizes the optimal mechanism for this problem setting. 3. Describes the qualitative properties of the derived optimal mechanism.
items.summary: This paper addresses the problem of efficiently allocating a shared resource, like radio spectrum, between non-commercial incumbents and commercial users when direct monetary transfers are infeasible and both parties hold private information. The authors propose a new mechanism design framework that incorporates costly inspections to verify claims. They characterize the optimal mechanism and describe its key properties for achieving efficient allocation under these constraints.

items.title: Centralization and Stability in Formal Constitutions
items.authors: Yotam Gafni
items.contributions: 1. Introduces the formal concept of a "self-maintaining" Social Choice Function (SCF), which is stable against being replaced by another SCF through its own voting process. 2. Proves a dynamic impossibility theorem (an "Arrow-Style" Theorem for Dynamics) showing that under i.i.d. unbiased beliefs, only dictatorships are self-maintaining. 3. Models the wisdom of the crowd effect to show how the stable size of a ruling elite decreases with economic extractiveness and improves in individual decision quality.
items.summary: This paper studies the stability of voting rules (Social Choice Functions) in formal systems like DAOs, where the rules themselves can be voted on. It introduces the concept of a "self-maintaining" SCF and analyzes its implications for centralization. The main findings are that, under certain conditions, only dictatorial rules are stable, and the stable size of a ruling elite shrinks with a more extractive economy or better individual decision-making.

items.title: Mechanism-Based Intelligence (MBI): Differentiable Incentives for Rational Coordination and Guaranteed Alignment in Multi-Agent Systems
items.authors: Stefano Grassi
items.institution: None (No affiliation or email domain provided in the given content)
items.contributions: 1. Proposes Mechanism-Based Intelligence (MBI), a new paradigm framing intelligence as emergent from the coordination of multiple agents. 2. Introduces the Differentiable Price Mechanism (DPM), which computes exact loss gradients as incentive signals to guarantee Dominant Strategy Incentive Compatibility and convergence. 3. Demonstrates a framework that scales linearly with the number of agents, bypassing Dec-POMDP complexity and showing significant empirical speedup over model-free RL.
items.summary: The paper addresses the fragility of multi-agent systems in coordinating private information and aligning incentives. It proposes Mechanism-Based Intelligence (MBI) and its core Differentiable Price Mechanism (DPM), which uses differentiable incentives to align agent actions with global objectives. The method guarantees incentive compatibility, scales efficiently, and is shown to be much faster than standard reinforcement learning approaches.

items.title: (Im)possibility of Incentive Design for Challenge-based Blockchain Protocols
items.authors: Suhyeon Lee, Dieu-Huyen Nguyen, Donghwan Lee
items.contributions: 1. A formal model for analyzing incentive design in challenge-based blockchain protocols, incorporating a colluding minority, heterogeneous costs, and three ordering modes. 2. A theoretical impossibility or limitation result for achieving honest non-loss and fraud deterrence in single-winner challenge protocol designs. 3. A positive result showing that multi-winner designs can achieve both goals under simple, explicit conditions.
items.summary: This paper investigates whether challenge-based blockchain protocols (like optimistic rollups) can properly incentivize honest challengers and punish dishonest proposers. By building a formal model, the authors find that single-winner designs cannot reliably achieve these goals, but multi-winner designs can under specific conditions.

items.title: Policy-Conditioned Policies for Multi-Agent Task Solving
items.authors: Yue Lin, Shuhui Zhu, Wenhao Li, Ang Li, Dan Qiao, Pascal Poupart, Hongyuan Zha, Baoxiang Wang
items.institution: The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen; University of Waterloo; Tongji University; Vector Institute
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a paradigm shift by representing agent policies as human-interpretable source code, bridging the gap between opaque neural policies and the need for strategy comprehension in multi-agent settings. 2. Introduces Programmatic Iterated Best Response (PIBR), a novel algorithm that uses LLMs as point-wise best-response operators to synthesize and refine policy code based on game utility and unit tests. 3. Operationalizes the game-theoretic concept of Program Equilibrium for modern learning, demonstrating its effectiveness on coordination games and a cooperative foraging environment.
items.summary: This paper addresses the challenge of dynamic strategy adaptation in multi-agent tasks by representing policies as interpretable source code and using Large Language Models (LLMs) to optimize them. The core method, Programmatic Iterated Best Response (PIBR), leverages LLMs to iteratively refine an agent's policy code in response to an opponent's strategy using textual feedback. The approach successfully solves standard coordination games and a cooperative environment, demonstrating a practical bridge between theoretical Program Equilibrium and modern AI learning.

items.title: Data Valuation for LLM Fine-Tuning: Efficient Shapley Value Approximation via Language Model Arithmetic
items.authors: Mélissa Tamine, Otmane Sakhi, Benjamin Heymann
items.institution: Criteo AI Lab, Fairplay joint team
items.summary: This paper proposes an efficient method for computing Shapley values to value data contributions for LLM fine-tuning. It leverages the specific mathematical structure of Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) to enable scalable Shapley value approximation without requiring numerous model retrainings. The main conclusion is that this approach dramatically simplifies the computational challenge of data valuation for LLMs, unlocking applications in data markets and collaborative training.

items.title: Ev-Trust: A Strategy Equilibrium Trust Mechanism for Evolutionary Games in LLM-Based Multi-Agent Services
items.authors: Shiduo Yang, Jiye Wang, Jiayu Qin, Jianbin Li, Yu Wang, Yuanhe Zhao, Kenan Guo
items.institution: State Grid Corporation of China, North China Electric Power University
items.summary: The paper proposes Ev-Trust, a trust mechanism based on evolutionary game theory that integrates direct trust, indirect trust, and expected revenue to guide agent behavior in LLM-based multi-agent systems. Theoretical analysis proves the stability of evolutionary equilibria, and experiments show the approach reduces malicious strategies and increases collective revenue in open service interactions.

items.title: Stackelberg Learning from Human Feedback: Preference Optimization as a Sequential Game
items.authors: Barna Pásztor, Thomas Kleine Buening, Andreas Krause
items.summary: This paper introduces Stackelberg Learning from Human Feedback (SLHF), a new framework that frames preference optimization as a sequential-move game between a Leader and a Follower policy. It demonstrates that this approach offers advantages in consistency, data sensitivity, and robustness to intransitive preferences compared to RLHF and NLHF. Experiments on large language models show that SLHF achieves strong alignment and enables inference-time refinements that transfer across model families.

items.title: A Decision-Theoretic Approach for Managing Misalignment
items.authors: Daniel A. Herrmann, Abinav Chari, Isabelle Qian, Sree Sharvesh, B. A. Levinstein
items.institution: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Georgia Institute of Technology, University of California, Berkeley, Amrita Vishwa Vidyapeetham, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
items.summary: This paper introduces a formal, decision-theoretic framework to analyze when to delegate decisions to an AI agent by balancing its value alignment, epistemic accuracy, and reach. It concludes that universal delegation requires near-perfect alignment, but context-specific delegation can be optimal even with significant misalignment if the agent's superior accuracy or expanded reach offers a net benefit.
